tn.text: This word is used here to mark a break in the main event. Here the author starts to tell a new part of the narrative. If you have a way of doing this in your language, consider using it here. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_newevent]])
"3" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
This is a basket made from a tall grass that grows by the Nile River in Egypt.

tn.ref: sealed it with bitumen and pitch
tn.text: You could explicitly state that this was to keep out water. AT: "spread tar on it to keep water from getting into it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here "sealed" means that she applied a waterproof coating.
This is a sticky black paste made from petroleum. It can be used to keep out water. AT: "tar" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])

This is a sticky brown or black paste that can be made from tree sap or from petroleum. Therefore, "pitch" would include not only "bitumen" but also plant-based resins. It too can be used to keep out water. AT: "tar" or "resin" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])
These "reeds" were a type of tall grass that grew in flat, wet areas.
This means she stood far enough away so that she would not be noticed, but close enough to see the basket.
"servants"
The word "behold" signals the surprising information that follows.
"breastfeed"
"the Hebrew woman brought him"
"he became the adopted son of Pharaoh's daughter"

tn.ref: Because I drew him from the water
tn.text: Translators may add a footnote that says "The name Moses sounds like the Hebrew word that means 'pull.'"
"pulled him"
"hitting" or "beating"

tn.ref: He looked this way and that way
tn.text: These two opposite directions have the combined meaning of "everywhere." AT: "He looked all around" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])
"Moses went out"
The word "behold" here shows that Moses was surprised by what he saw. You can use a word in your language that will give this meaning.

tn.ref: the one who was in the wrong
tn.text: This was a customary way of saying "the one who started the fight." AT: "the one who was guilty of starting the fight" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: Who made you a leader and judge over us?
tn.text: The man used this question to rebuke Moses for intervening in the fight. AT: "You are not our leader and have no right to judge us!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Are you planning to kill me as you killed that Egyptian?
tn.text: The man used a question here to be sarcastic. AT: "We know that you killed an Egyptian yesterday. You had better not kill me!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Now when Pharaoh heard about it
tn.text: The word "now" is used here to mark a break in the event. Here the author starts to tell a new part of the incident.

tn.ref: Now the priest of Midian had seven daughters
tn.text: The word "now" is used here to mark a break in the event. Here the author tells about new people in the narrative.
This means that they brought up water from a well.
a long, narrow, open container for animals to eat or drink out of
"chase them away"
"rescued them"

tn.ref: Why did you leave the man?
tn.text: This question is a mild rebuke to the daughters for not inviting Moses into their home according to the normal hospitality of that culture. AT: "You should not have left this man at the well!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Moses agreed to stay with the man
tn.text: "Moses agreed to live with Reuel"
This is Reuel's daughter. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is Moses's son. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"stranger in a foreign land"
They did this because of their sorrow and misery. AT: "sighed deeply"

tn.ref: their pleas went up to God
tn.text: The cries of the Israelites are spoken of as if they were a person and were able to travel up to where God is. AT: "God heard their pleas" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: God called to mind his covenant
tn.text: This was a customary way of saying God thought about what He had promised. AT: "God remembered his covenant" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
